The Elder Subhaddā’s Birth Story
Padumuttara, the knower of the world,
the receiver of offerings,
having delivered the people,
the one of great fame, will attain Nibbāna.
And as the Sambuddha is attaining Nibbāna,
the ten-thousand world systems will quake;
There will be a great crowd of people,
and the gods will gather at that time.
Having filled it with sandalwood,
and with tagara and jasmine flowers,
with a mind full of joy, I will place
the highest of men on the pyre.
Knowing my thought,
the unsurpassed teacher in the world,
the Sambuddha, while lying down,
recited these verses:
‘He who, in my final hour,
covered me with a fragrant garland,
I will praise him,
listen to me as I speak.
From here, this person,
will go to the Tusita host;
Having reigned there,
he will go to the (god’s) creation.
By this very method,
having given the most excellent garland,
he, being satisfied with his own deeds,
will experience good fortune.
Again, in the Tusita host,
will be reborn as a human being.
Having passed away from that realm,
he will go to the human state.
The great elephant, the Sakyan Son,
the foremost in the world with its gods;
Having enlightened many beings,
the one with vision will attain Nibbāna.
Then, having approached,
urged on by the root of merit,
having approached the Sambuddha,
he will ask a question then.
Having made the Sambuddha laugh,
the all-knowing leader of the world;
having fully understood his meritorious deeds,
he will reveal the Truths.
And this question will be begun,
satisfied, with a one-pointed mind;
having worshipped the Teacher,
he will request the going forth.
Seeing his mind is clear,
satisfied with his own deed;
that Buddha will give him the going forth,
skilled in the foremost path.
Having striven in this way,
in the dispensation of the Sambuddha;
having fully understood all the pollutants,
he will attain Nibbāna, without pollutants’.
The fifth recitation-section.
Connected with his previous deed,
one-pointed, well-composed;
the Buddha’s bosom-born son,

For a hundred thousand eons,
The leader of the highest lotus;
He attained Nibbāna without attachment,
Like a lamp with the exhaustion of oil.
It was seven leagues in extent,
And the shrine was made of jewels;
I worshipped there the flag,
The most auspicious, delightful.
And for the Buddha Kassapa,
A disciple named Tissa;
He was my own son,
An heir to the Jina's Dispensation.
With a lowly mind,
I spoke harsh words, not auspicious;
By the ripening of that kamma,
Later, I had what was auspicious.
